awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Mathematical Models and Computational Methods for the Tumor Microenvironment
awd_abstract_narration:
The main objective of this work is to develop comprehensive mathematical models and computational methods at the microscale for the emergence of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and the transition to invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) both in vivo and in vitro microfluidic devices. The investigator and his colleagues develop computational methods for the microenvironment models based on integrated second-order finite volume methods for each of the system components - fluid mechanics, chemical and ion transport in the bulk fluid, reactions on the cell membrane, transport through the cell membrane, and fluid/structure interaction of the elastic biological cells. The modeling innovation includes the incorporation of ion transport, reaction, and diffusion in a cells-based model with detailed membrane reaction kinetics and membrane transport. This is coupled with internal kinetics and growth processes of individual cells. Another innovation is the incorporation of Lagrangian mesh based models for the viscoelastic properties of matrigel and extracellular matrix.

Breast cancer is the second-leading cause of death in women in developed countries. In USA alone, 230,480 women were diagnosed with invasive breast cancer in 2011 and an estimated 57,650 women were tested positive with non invasive ductal carcinoma (DCIS). Although DCIS itself is not life-threatening, it has a high probability of progression to IDC if left untreated. In this project, the investigator and his colleagues study tumor microenvironments in DCIS and its progression to IDC. Successful completion of this project provides a fundamental change in modeling of tumor evolution where the identity of each cell is of importance. Although focus has been placed on modeling ductal carcinoma, one can extend these techniques to the study of variety of biological processes. A number of research fields are benefited from this work. These include cell biology, systems biology, biomedical engineering, computational fluid mechanics, and applied and computational mathematics.  In addition to this technical impact, the project provides a unique educational opportunity to train graduate and undergraduate students as well as high school teachers in multidisciplinary environments.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Ductal carcinomas are a hallmark of several cancer types including breast, prostate and salivary cancers. Our main objective is to develop comprehensive mathematical models and computational methods at the microscale for the emergence of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and the transition to invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) both in vivo and in vitro microfluidic devices. Here we focus on development of methods for modeling the tumor microenvironment on scales involving a few to hundreds of cells. The goal is to develop models that incorporate ion transport, reaction, and diffusion in a cells-based model with detailed membrane reaction kinetics and membrane transport coupled with internal kinetics and growth processes of individual cells. A central phenomonen the transition from DCIS to IDC is differentiation of fibroblasts surrounding the ducts into inflammatory myofibroblasts that support the progress of tumor cell evolution and matastisis. The transition from normal fibroblasts to myofibroblasts is dependent on growth and other factors secreted from the tumor cells as well as remodeling of the extracellular matrix induced by the fibroblasts themselves.

 

 

In this research, we have developed  models for the tumor microenvironment in DCIS for a small numbers of discrete cells including including models for the viscoelastic and mechanical properties of the extracellular matrix. These models will eventually be extended to models involving many discrete cells. Our models include cellular metabolism. In the low oxygen regime of tumor growth, cells secrete higher levels of H+ into the microenvironment leading to an increase in acidityin the microenvironmnet. In this high acidity environment, the fitness of tumor cells is increased with respect to normal cells. We have also dqeveloped models for autocrine signaling of the growth factor TGF-β, activation by secreted matrix metalloproteinases, as well as  autocrine signaling and crosstalk of the stromal cell derived factor SDF-1. The intracellular processes are modeled as coupled systems of ODEs, the interaction of the diffusible factors with cell membrane receptors and secretion of proteins and ions into the extracellular environment. We have adapted a second-order immersed interface method to model the interaction of the signaling molecules with cell-receptors and the secretion of intracellular products through the cell membrane. This model requires the solution of a system of ODEs in the intracellular space with Nernst-Planck equation for ions and reaction-diffusion equations in the extracellular space.  We have now incorporated receptor trafficking into the TGF-β models.  In this mechanism, TGF-β bound receptors are internalized. The receptors are recycled, but TGF-β is degraded.  We have successfully tuned the model parameters to match (qualitatively)  a set of cell-culture experimental results (Clark et al, 2009).  The experiments introduced a bolus of TGF-β in an epithelial cell line over a broad range of TGF concentrations.  Measurements of TGF-β concentration and cellular activated Smad levels were obtained over a 24 hour period. Typically mathematical models of cellular protein/gene systems include a number of parameters. We have developed a Bayesian heirarchical method for estimating parameters in ODE models. We compared the heirarchical method with a simpler traditional Bayesian method and found that the heirarchical model is superior in cases where there is insufficient data in comparison with the number of parameters. Our "best fit" numerical results to the TGF-beta data suggest that autocrine TGF-beta signaling is required to account for the experimental results using models with fixed parameters over such a broad range of initial TGF-beta concentrations.

 

This research grant has supported three full-time graduate students in the field of computational biology. Two will be awarded doctorates in Mathematics in Spring, 2018. One will obtain a doctorate in Mechanical Engineering in Spring, 2019.


Last Modified: 10/30/2017
Modified by: Robert H Dillon
